message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with endometriosis, which is characterized by pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and nodules on rectovaginal examination. Ovarian cysts may cause similar symptoms, but they typically do not cause tender nodules on rectovaginal examination. Diverticulitis and PID usually do not cause pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, or dyspareunia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including painful intercourse, painful defecation, and heavy menses with severe cramps, suggest Endometriosis. The left-deviated tender cervix, tender retroverted uterus, and left adnexal mass with nodules during rectovaginal examination are also consistent with Endometriosis. Ovarian cyst and PID may present with similar symptoms, but the physical findings in this case suggest Endometriosis as the most likely diagnosis. Diverticulitis typically presents with lower abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest endometriosis. The nodules noted during rectovaginal examination are a hallmark of endometriosis. Ovarian cysts may present with similar symptoms, but there is a palpable mass in this case. Diverticulitis and PID are less likely to present with these symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has several symptoms that suggest endometriosis, including painful defecation, painful micturition, painful sexual intercourse, heavy menstrual bleeding, and lower abdominal tenderness with nodules noted during rectovaginal examination. The left adnexal mass and retroverted uterus also suggest endometriosis. None of the other options fully explain all of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including painful defecation, painful micturition, and pain during sexual intercourse, and the physical examination findings of a left-deviated tender cervix, a tender retroverted uterus, and nodules during rectovaginal examination, suggest the most likely diagnosis is endometriosis. The left adnexal mass is also suggestive of endometriosis. Ovarian cysts usually do not cause the patient's constellation of symptoms, and diverticulitis is a condition of the large intestine. PID could cause lower pelvic pain, but it is rare to have nodules during rectovaginal examination with PID.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of painful intercourse, painful defecation, heavy menstrual bleeding, and a tender uterus, which are all common symptoms of Endometriosis. The left adnexal mass and nodules found during the rectovaginal exam also support this diagnosis. Ovarian cysts may cause similar symptoms, but they usually do not cause nodules during a rectovaginal exam, and tenderness is usually prominent on one side of the abdomen rather than generalized. Diverticulitis is unlikely as the tenderness is not localized to the left lower abdomen only, and there are no symptoms of diarrhea or fever. PID is also unlikely given the absence of specific signs such as cervical motion tenderness or fever.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic website for help. The patient has symptoms such as painful periods, painful intercourse, and constipation, which are strongly associated with endometriosis. The left adnexal mass and nodules found during the physical examination support the diagnosis of endometriosis. Ovarian cysts can cause pelvic pain, but they do not explain the other symptoms. Diverticulitis does not typically cause gynecologic symptoms. PID can cause pelvic pain but typically presents with fever, vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and physical exam findings that suggest endometriosis, including severe lower abdominal cramps during menses, painful defecation, painful sexual intercourse, and nodules on rectovaginal exam. The left adnexal mass also suggests endometriosis. Ovarian cysts and PID may have similar symptoms, but the adnexal mass and nodules make endometriosis more likely. Diverticulitis would not cause these gynecologic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest endometriosis. The heavy menstrual bleeding and severe lower abdominal cramps after menstruation are typical symptoms of endometriosis. Pain during sexual intercourse is another common symptom. The left-deviated tender cervix, tender retroverted uterus, and left adnexal mass along with nodules during rectovaginal examination favor the diagnosis of endometriosis. Ovarian cyst may present as an adnexal mass, but it would not cause tenderness or nodules on rectovaginal examination. Diverticulitis presents with a palpable mass and fever, which are not present in this case. Pelvic inflammatory disease usually presents with fever and leukocytosis, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest endometriosis, as she has painful intercourse, constipation, painful micturition, heavy menses, and pelvic pain that is relieved with pain medication. The physical examination findings of a left-deviated tender cervix, a tender retroverted uterus, a left adnexal mass, and nodules during the rectovaginal examination all support this diagnosis. Other options such as ovarian cyst, diverticulitis, and PID do not explain all the symptoms and findings.
